settings.blog-title: WHAT TO WEAR TO A WEDDING IN THE SUMMER

settings.text: There’s one time of year when our calendars tend to be booked out. When the days get longer, warmer and brighter, it makes the perfect wedding backdrop. So if every weekend of your summer is booked out with celebrations, deciding on what to wear to each can be almost a minefield. To help you navigate, follow Chinti & Parker’s invaluable guide to being the best-dressed guest.

settings.grid-content:
1. No white, of course

The number one rule of any wedding is only the brides wear white. That includes any shades such as ivory, cream, eggshell, vanilla… We would even recommend you avoid any hues that are too pale; light pink and soft grey spring to mind. Of course, it all depends on the theme, but this is the general rule.

If a revealing neckline or cut has caught your eye, consider clearing it with the bride before wearing. Whilst she will likely have no qualms, she’ll appreciate you checking in.

2. Lightweight fabrics are a must

Although the infamous British weather can turn at a moment’s notice, light and airy fabrics are still a must for the summer season. Depending on venues, you may be inside for extended periods of time, or standing outside for photos under the midday sun. Some locations may have air conditioning, others may not. It’s a difficult balance to maintain. Lightweight fabrics are your safest option. Have a chic blazer, cardigan or pashmina to hand to layer if there’s a chill in the air or when evening rolls around

3. Pastels for grown-ups

Summer weddings and pastels go hand-in-hand, yet some guests avoid them for fear of looking too girly. This wedding season, embrace femininity. Floaty dresses and silhouettes are ideal for warm evening celebrations. Add ‘grown-up’ touches with sky-high heels and metallic accessories that will help bring the whimsy back to earth.

4. Modern neutrals

For many, pastels and bold hues are a step too far out of their comfort zone. If that rings true for you, it doesn’t mean you can’t be wedding-ready. Earthy tones such as khaki, sage, rust or even a burnt orange - if you may be so bold - toe the line between bright and neutral to see you through the wedding season.

5. Fall back on classics

Jeans and a nice top’ but for weddings. For a tried-and-tested combination that works for many a formal occasion, look for a colourful and floaty midi skirt - ideally bold or patterned - and balance with a slimming top in a dark neutral shade, such as black. A timeless bandeau or top with a square neckline will show off your décolletage. Sophistication in an instant.

6. Chic tailoring

Forego the unwritten rule of dresses at a wedding. If ultra-feminine isn’t quite your style, a tailored and slimming suit will look effortlessly chic and timeless. Avoid neutrals and opt again for playful pastels to avoid looking like you’re ready for a day in the boardroom. Be wedding-ready with strappy summer heels and statement accessories.

7. Terrain-suitable shoes

Heel wearers everywhere will understand the perils of walking on grass. Leave your stilettos at home this time, as they will let you down when faced with cobbles, grass and gravel. Kitten heels are for prom night, and boots are an absolute no-go. Instead, opt for platforms and classic wedges. Tuck a slim pair of suitable flats into your bag for when mid-evening foot pain emerges to avoid being the one who goes barefoot on the dancefloor.

8. Barely big-enough bags

It goes without saying that you don’t want to be burdened as you navigate the day. That being said, choose wisely when it comes to your bag. Clutches evoke images of prom night and can quickly become an annoyance when you are left with only one hand free. A small top-handle bag can nestle in the crook of your arm and has just enough room for your essentials. A small cross-body can also hang delicately off your shoulder and blends in amongst the folds of floaty dresses and skirts.
